content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; in about 20 minutes, we’ll be having a meeting to discuss the proposed document that lists the "Guiding Principles for Compiler Contributors”. We’ll allocate time at the start of the meeting to read the doc itself, which is here: https://hackmd.io/TYGRjVIbSBmxpbcfDzll-w?view
Okay, hi again @T-compiler/meeting , the steering meeting is starting now. Leave a :wave: to show you are here!
Before we get started on the topic of this meeting itself, I wanted to point you all at #project leads (public) > six years of Rust blog post

If there’s anything from the last year that you think is particularly worth shouting out for the project’s six birthday, please do check if its covered there, and if its not, add your voice to the conversation!

For this meeting, I wanted to again try the approach of having everyone quietly read the doc and then have us all start giving feedback here. (You can also leave comments on the doc in the right-hand pane, though hackmd’s commenting can be wonky sometimes.)
I have some general thoughts, but I'm not sure where I should put them

Lets use a similar protocol to what I did in the musl meeting: tag this message with :book: when you start reading, and tag it with :checkered_flag: when you stop. That way, when the two counts are equal, I’ll knowwe’re done.
should I just hold on to them ? :)
I think hold on to them, or add a comment on the title maybe?
I also have feedback on a specific particular point, not sure where to put them (esp. since I don't want to log into hackmd or similar)
Lets allocate 10 minutes for reading. I’ll post here again to see if people need more time at that point, at 18 minutes past the hour

I also have feedback on a specific particular point, not sure where to put them (esp. since I don't want to log into hackmd or similar)

Ah, not wanting to log into hackmd is a legitimate concern. I think I’d still prefer we save the comments (the ones posted here in this topic, that is) until everyone has had a chance to read
yeah, thats fine I think, I'll just write up a draft.
Okay I think we are only waiting on @nikomatsakis
you want the full ten minutes, niko?
I do :)
Okay, no problem.
ok

so before we start
there’s one thing I wanted to mention
There was a thing in the news this last week
about the linux foundation banning university of minnestoa
if you don’t know the story, I cannot take time to explain it here
but the thing I wanted to say
part of the story is a research paper, with the advice, “Maybe the Code of Conduct should include a point saying “I do not intend to deliberately submit buggy code."
I found this laughable when I read it
but the thing is: Even though I found that laughable
I realized soon afterward that many of you might find items on this list laughable
and that’s okay. I welcome that feedback
(Context: https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/linux-bans-university-of-minnesota-for-committing-malicious-code/)
laughable why? because so obvious?
Yes
Well, this relates to my concern in a significant way, but in the other direction – I think Rust is a Product section captures it.
Anyway, that was all I wanted to open with. If you think this exercise is just spinning our wheels, I want to talk aboutthat

nikomatsakis said:

laughable why? because so obvious?

well and because it doesn't actually do anything :laughing: "yes, I a bad guy promise not to do bad things"

Which brings me to my prepared draft:

So my concern is about considering Rust to be a Product. I think phrasing it this way will make contributors who contribute their own time wary of contributing. Ultimately to me this means that the product/business needs might trump the overall direction that the project would be better off with. Explanation goes into a further detail, which I agree with to a fair extent (especially wrt it not being a research project). IOW I don't think summarizing it as a "Product" is the right approach. I think it has too much baggage and implications that might not be what we want to portray.
That’s great feedback
I had some related thoughts
For one thing, there are a lot of principles in this list, and it's kind of hard to wrap my head around them;
so I started thinking about how I might simplify them, or consolidate them
It sounds like @nagisa you do see what I was trying to express
I got to thinking about three core principles:
in terms of wanting to say “We are not a testbed"
(at least, not anymore)

• Kind to each other
  • Kind to our users
  • Kind to new contributors
the middle one was meant to cover "Rust is a product"-- but also some other things, like "we don't immediately fix bugs that will have impact on the ecosystem; we phase in those changes"
Hmm. So a problem with reducing it to sucha small number of principles
is that the fine-grain ordering, I think, might matter
yeah, I wondered about that
i'm not actually suggesting those as "the 3 principles" necessarily
E.g. I myself struggled with how to order “Keep the trains” running in the list
(In case people missed it at the outset of the doc: This is an ordered list. The top items was meant to be prioritized over the later ones.)
the other thing i was thinking about is what are some of the difficult decisions we've had to make over the years, and how are they reflected in this list?
some examples I came up with:
• whether to revert a buggy PR or to fix it in place
• whether to fix a bug immediately or to do a future-compatibility warning or perhaps just to accept the behavior as "unfortunate but binding"
• how much tech debt to take on in pursuit of shipping
whether to accept a PR that provides important work, or delay so that it can be rewritten
• whether to accept prs that have a bunch of nits that are unrelated to the primary task (or perhaps are the entire PR)
(I guess that’s an instance of your tech debt bullet)
that's kind of what I meant
I was thinking of parallel rustc

I think having a smaller list would be more impactful. IMO part of the point of principles is that you derive other values from them.

In particular, the last three on the list currently ("Every little bit helps", "Err on the side of exposition", and "Value practical portabilty") don't feel like principles to me, they feel like they're derived from the others on the list.
yes, I thought that many of the items could be pulled into exposition

nikomatsakis said:

the other thing i was thinking about is what are some of the difficult decisions we've had to make over the years, and how are they reflected in this list?

I've found this to be a really helpful framework for deriving these sorts of principles
and figuring out the ordering between them
Pulling more stuff into exposition would be fine, yeah
maybe I should make a new doc where we can sketch out the problem lists
yes, hard decisions or tricky situation list
that would be really interesting to me
https://hackmd.io/awoymhnuQoGABt22e7JJBw
We can just put them in notes for this meeting for now

reading over the list, I felt like this would likely wind up being generalizable to a template for other teams as well; i think for now though we should just focus on rust compiler, but one could imaine having general contributor principles, with some things specific to the compiler added later
oh, there is one other thing I did want to mention that I forgot about until now
I've been working slowly on async rust guiding principles and I came to an interesting realization
Whether we would potentially want/need distinct lists for the compiler team itself versus the entirety of the compiler contributors

it doesn't sound as "commercial"
